awd_titl_txt: Conference: 57th Spring Topology and Dynamical Systems Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal supports the 57th annual Spring Topology and Dynamical Systems conference (STDC), hosted this year at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte.   The conference encourages participation from a broad spectrum of mathematicians at different career levels and diverse backgrounds and implements a recruitment strategy that starts with establishing a diverse cohort of session organizers.  Elements of the conference include providing pathways to including mathematicians into the community, such as dissemination of results through the conference affiliated journal Topology Proceedings.   Conference funds will be used to support graduate students and early career participants, as well as established mathematicians without other sources of travel support and invited speakers.

The 57th STDC will be the latest in an annual series that began in 1967 and will continue its tradition of bringing together researcher from the around the world and from a range of currently active areas of topology.  Over the years, the conference has structured itself around a core of special sessions representing strands of topology-related fields of interest.  The 57th STDC will feature sessions focused on Continuum Theory, Dynamical Systems, Geometric Group Theory, Geometric Topology, and Set-Theoretic Topology.  More information about the conference is available at: https://pages.charlotte.edu/stdc2024/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of North Carolina at Charlotte was proud to host the 57th Spring Topology and Dynamics Conference (the STDC, for short) from March 6-9 on our campus in Charlotte, NC. Since the STDC began in 1967 (then known as the Spring Topology Conference), this conference series has been one of the largest and most successful annual topology conferences worldwide. 

The STDC has had an enormous impact on the mathematical community over the 59 years of its history. The conference has always encouraged the participation of a broad spectrum of mathematicians: researchers of all nationalities and backgrounds; women and men; from small colleges and large universities; young students, seasoned researchers, and emeritus professors. The 57th STDC was proud to continue this tradition, and to bring a diverse cohort of world-class researchers to Charlotte last spring.

The conference saw a total of 133 researchers, 113 participating in person with an additional 20 joining virtually. The conference is organized around 5 key areas in topology: Continuum Theory, Dynamical Systems, Geometric Group Theory, Geometric Topology, and Set-Theoretic Topology. These areas are closely related, and the STDC provides an opportunity for mathematicians working in these areas to come together, to tell each other about the most important advances of the past year, and to collaborate with one another. In addition, the STDC reserves a plenary address for the winner of the annual Mary Ellen Rudin Young Researcher award, which is given to an early-career topologist with outstanding contributions to the field. This year's winner was Yvon Verberne of the University of Western Ontario.

The funding provided by the NSF was used primarily to support the travel of researchers to the conference. The conference program included 15 main speakers, all of whom were offered travel support. Additionally, we were able to fund or partially fund the travel of 37 other researchers. Some of these are graduate students or early Ph.D.'s, and some more seasoned researchers whose institutions are unable to fund their travel. Without the help of the NSF, this conference would have been much smaller, much less diverse, and less productive. 

The NSF provided a total of $43,431 for this conference. The original amount of the award was $33,000, and $10,431 in supplementary funding was provided later when it became clear just how many researchers were in need of travel assistance. Nearly all of this money went to travel support, although a small amount was used for local logistics. The remainder of the conference's funding was obtained from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and from a registration fee paid by the conference attendees.
